Subject: [TRUB] mash rests (was: Oatmeal Stout)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit



On Wed, 14 Oct 1998 Dedpetvet@aol.com wrote:
> The temp of 120 F. is from Michael Lewis's book on Stout.  I think that beta
> gluconase has a wide temp range.  The advantage of the 120 is that you are in
> the prime area for protein digestion too.  Kevin, you seem to have
> considerable experience with beta-gluconase.  Doese it remove the silky mouth
> feel?

I don't want to pretend I know more than I really do (people
start to take you real seriously when you use lots of words
that end in "-ase" ;-) and unfortunately I've never gone to
the trouble of brewing the same recipe with and without a
rest at 104.  So what I can tell you is this: for the last oatmeal
stout I brewed I used both wheat and oats, and did a rest at
104 and skipped the protein rest.  It was perfectly silky, which I
attribute to a dextrin-promoting saccharification rest at around 158.

Some other tidbits: it is correct that beta glucanase has a wide
range of activity, and is still active in the 120-125 degree range.
However, in this temp range (where many people do there protein
rests), your peptidases are active, munching small proteins.
This is what you want to use when you're using lots of starch
adjuncts, because you need those peptides to act as yeast nutrients.
When you use all malt, you have plenty of yeast nutrient, and those
peptidases may actually be working against you by munching "friendly"
head-promoting proteins.  So, when I'm not using starch adjuncts and 
think I need a protein rest, I do the protein rest at 135, where the
proteases are more active than the peptidases, breaking down the larger
haze-promoting proteins but not smaller head-promoting proteins.

Disclaimer:  I got a B- in college biology.  I'm largely
parroting what I've read in Fix and in Papazian and from the
collective wisdom of rec.crafts.brewing.  I may have gotten a few
terms mixed up, but I believe the gist of this to be accurate.
Oh, and I don't really believe that any proteins are inherently
more "friendly" than any other proteins.

Kevin.
